“I am an old man. I don’t care [what happens to me],” he said.
Young _čuuwin_ felt brave thanks to him [the old man].
They took him.

transcript.default: ḥaʔakʔanits ɬim̓aqsti waaʔaƛquuč mixtukʔi, ʔuyiʔaƛ̓atquuč naqsaap̓at, qʷišaa.

transcription.default: ḥaʔakʔanits ɬim̓aqsti waaʔaƛquuč mixtukʔi ʔuyiʔaƛ̓atquuč naqsaap̓at qʷišaa

translation.eng: “I was brave. They made me drink tabacco [and I was brave enough to actually drink it],” the old man used to say.
It was probably tea that he was served. He had tea.
This native man thought he was given chewing tobacco [when he saw tea leaves at the bottom of his cup].
“They must have been trying to kill me,” he used to say.
Sometimes the tea was sweet.

transcript.default: hač̓a šuukʷaa ʔuyiiʔanitʔaaɬ, qʷiyiiʔanitii [brown sugar], naqšiʔaƛquuč.

transcription.default: hač̓a šuukʷaa ʔuyiiʔanitʔaaɬ qʷiyiiʔanitii [brown sugar] naqšiʔaƛquuč

translation.eng: Maybe they gave him white sugar or something like brown sugar when he drank the tea.
They left for Victoria.
They departed.
I could say “sailed away”.
The British people were sailing away — maybe on a steam boat. It was probably a steam boat.

transcript.default: pitiš. pitiš waa, minwaaʔatḥ. pitiš. wicikʔaɬ British waa. pitiš. pitiš.

translation.eng: They called British Navy soldiers “_pitiš_”. They couldn’t say “British”.

transcription.default: aqukʷitii yaqckʷiiyii [King George] waaʔaƛ̓anitʔaaɬ ƛaḥ [nineteen twenty] [early nineteen twenties]

translation.eng: The person on the throne and his descendants were called “King George” recently — early 1920′s.
Native people used to say “We are King George people”.
They took the [British] flag very seriously.
We have the Union Jack. They gave native people the flag.
They were also really excited [about the flag].

transcript.default: ḥaw̓iɬukʷit, yaʕaƛitii Benson kapčaa, ʔunaak ʔuyiiʔaƛ̓atƛa, [Union Jack].

translation.eng: The former chief Benson, _kapčaa_ had one. He was also given the Union Jack.
He had a sword, too.

translation.eng: Nobody knows whatever happened to the sword. _č̓it̓u:ɬ_ — this is how they called it.
The [old] man was gone for a long time. He went to Victoria for a long time.
They took him back as far as Tofino and dropped him off there.
He told his people about the way they treated him.

translation.eng: He thought they were going to kill him [by making him drink tobacco] although they only served him tea.
And sometimes whatever they served him had a really strong (bitter) taste.

translation.eng: Because the only thing British Navy soldiers had was liquor, i.e. rum — Indian people called it “_nam_”.
They used to serve him the hard thing — we called it Thing-Resembling-Sand-Dollar — it was probably biscuits.
They used to serve him salty things — salty meat.
Probably he was served salt pork.

translation.eng: This actually happened. It was probably a woman — a female body was split right in half.
Her innards were scattered all over on the side.
She was a very old woman. She was split right in half from here — from her private part [toward her head].
And also her head was shattered. It was smashed open.
They clubbed her.

translation.eng: For a long time, they never again traded sea otters or anything with them (Europeans).
They didn’t [trade with Europeans any more]. They gave up [trading with Europeans].
They only traded with other people.

translation.eng: And the native man on board the Kingfisher was also killed [by the Ahousaht warriors who attacked the ship].
One [of the warriors] wanted to save the native man’s life.
[But] they (the warriors) killed them (people on board the Kingfisher) all.

They (the warriors who opposed the idea of saving the native person on board the Kingfisher) said to him (the one who wanted to save the native person’s life), “we may have some trouble in the future [if we keep him alive].” But they were already in trouble [by killing the Englishmen on the ship].
This is what happened.
They made a mistake.
